text:
<https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_helm.html#preparing-for-validator-onboarding> look for

```If you want to only connect to a single trusted scan at TRUSTED_SCAN_URL but not obtain additional Scan URLs for BFT Scan reads, you can uncomment the following and set nonSvValidatorTrustSingleScan to true. This does mean that you depend on that single SV and if it is broken or malicious you will be unable to use the network so usually you want to default to not enabling this.```
Not recommend obviously but in case you really want to test out devnet.

elements.text: look for

If you want to only connect to a single trusted scan at TRUSTED_SCAN_URL but not obtain additional Scan URLs for BFT Scan reads, you can uncomment the following and set nonSvValidatorTrustSingleScan to true. This does mean that you depend on that single SV and if it is broken or malicious you will be unable to use the network so usually you want to default to not enabling this.
Not recommend obviously but in case you really want to test out devnet.

text: The PR is merged, You can start checking whitelist as soon as 2/3 whitelist, you can join the network. DevNet is self-service. For Testnet, ping me directly on slack to get a secret.

text: Is there a way to undo “pre-approve incoming direct transfers of canton coin”?

elements.text: Is there a way to undo “pre-approve incoming direct transfers of canton coin”?

text:
if you do it through config, just remove it.

if you do it by clicking the button on the ui, you can make this DELETE api call

*DELETE* /v0/admin/transfer-preapprovals/by-party/{receiver-party}

<https://docs.dev.sync.global/app_dev/validator_api/index.html#user-wallet-api>

elements.text:
if you do it through config, just remove it.

if you do it by clicking the button on the ui, you can make this DELETE api call
DELETE
/v0/admin/transfer-preapprovals/by-party/{receiver-party}

text:
Great to hear on DevNet! Same process for TestNet and MainNet with the one exception that the onboarding secret is provided by your SV Sponsor (in your case Digital Asset). You can DM me when you're ready for an onboarding secret

For each environment, you do need to check manually to see if the SVs have adopted your IP

text: what all does the wallet UI check when deciding whether to do onboarding? i.e., if i create user X in the ledger API with a primary party of party Y that was created during validator bootstrap, and ensure that actAs has been granted to user X for party Y, i would expect to be able to log into the wallet UI as X and see the wallet of party Y, same as if i logged in with the admin user defined in the Helm chart - however the UI still prompts me to onboard the user

text:
hey <@U0821PFKM0V> or <@U04KJF6UTNU>, whoever is able to be our sponsor and whitelist us - if you need any info on us, here are some links (we are a proven validator/infra provider in a multitude of networks):

• website: <https://pops.one> (mainnets include links to our validators as well)
• verified provider profile on Stakingrewards: <https://www.stakingrewards.com/provider/pops-team-validator>
• over 90 networks supported
• we work closely with Celestia, we designed and executed their whole incentivized testnet with 940 node operators and validators participating, we are incharge of their delegation program, run public good infra for them and run their backup SP1 provers for mainnet and testnet (supporting multiple EVM networks)
• teams like Celestia are able to vouch for us if needed and if you know someone there

Hello, I'm asking here as maybe someone have an idea what am I missing.

We catched up with network upgrades, set up fresh node, migrated node ID's and from the node perspective everything seems to be running fine, however it seems like network does not recognize our validator license

validator-1  | {"@timestamp":"2025-07-22T16:36:30.280Z","@version":"1","message":"The operation 'Check whether ValidatorLicense for Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80... is visible' failed with a retryable error (full stack trace omitted): NOT_FOUND: ValidatorLicense for Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80...\nstatusCode=NOT_FOUND","logger_name":"o.l.s.v.ValidatorApp:validator=validator_backend","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-32","level":"INFO","level_value":20000,"span-id":"a70a136109921a75","span-parent-id":"141dd87473848fe8","trace-id":"0d19b15d58a018f27fcf85d7a82d1621","span-name":"validator_license"}
we used node id dump out of our previous validator and according to validator logs it was properly imported

Participant is running without any issues, we are on migration 3 on 0.4.4 on mainnet
Thanks in advance

text: If you're spinning up a node but using a backup of your identies, that means you're going to use the same valdiator operator partyID: the same suffix / fingerprint (which is a hash of your public key) and the `validatorPartyHInt`. This will then allow you (require you) to reuse the existing onboarding secret for that validator operator

elements.text: If you're spinning up a node but using a backup of your identies, that means you're going to use the same valdiator operator partyID: the same suffix / fingerprint (which is a hash of your public key) and the
validatorPartyHInt
. This will then allow you (require you) to reuse the existing onboarding secret for that validator operator

text:
it's fine in this case. If you had create user with the primary party as of the validator operator ahead of time. Then you can also just click "onboarding myself", and it will work, and the user will have access to that wallet as well.

Similar to how you put them in the helm chart.

elements.text:
it's fine in this case. If you had create user with the primary party as of the validator operator ahead of time. Then you can also just click "onboarding myself", and it will work, and the user will have access to that wallet as well.

Similar to how you put them in the helm chart.

text:
That's exactly what I've did.
Party hint is the same (Lukka-Inc-prod-1),  party ID and suffix is the same (Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80bd69d5c18bd2059a62afd4375c8585b0a379d1189813d5ea558573be) and the onboarding secret is also the same

Only difference in new node is participant ID which changed from lukka-prod-1 to Lukka-Inc-prod-2 as per documentation that points out that it should differ when restoring validator from identities backup
<https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#re-onboard-a-validator-and-recover-balances-of-all-users-it-hosts>

In the logs it's even visible that proper party ID and suffix is used to call DA SV which returns 200 (ok) response on onboarding request.

```ValidatorRight for Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80... already exists, skipping

validator_backend app initialization: Onboard validator wallet users finished after PT0.262823703S"

validator_backend app initialization: Ensure validator is onboarded started

ValidatorLicense not found, onboarding is configured. Requesting onboarding with configured secret

Requesting to be onboarded by SV at: <https://sv.sv-2.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com>"

HTTP client (POST /api/sv/v0/onboard/validator): Received response with status code: 200 OK```
However the issue still remains and after set amount of retries node fails with

```The operation 'Check whether ValidatorLicense for Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80... is visible' failed with a retryable error (full stack trace omitted): NOT_FOUND```
And ultimately

```Gave up waiting until ValidatorLicense for Lukka-Inc-prod-1::1220728cfb80... is visible```

text:
Just curious. Is it possible to recover a validator node from the iddump after the migration id has changed?

And if yes, for how long does that work? E.g., if I have an iddump created at mig1, v0.2.4, will it be possible to recover the node now? :thinking_face:

elements.text:
Just curious. Is it possible to recover a validator node from the iddump after the migration id has changed?

And if yes, for how long does that work? E.g., if I have an iddump created at mig1, v0.2.4, will it be possible to recover the node now?

text:
The documentation is clear that there is risk involved. We use a simple script to create a backup to a folder. A separate script is doing the retention and rsync to an offsite storage server so that not included below:

```#!/bin/bash

# BACKUP DATABASES
backup_dir="/root/__backups"

mkdir -p "${backup_dir}"

docker exec -i splice-validator-postgres-splice-1 pg_dump -U cnadmin validator > "${backup_dir}"/validator-"$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%:z")".dump

sleep 2

active_participant_db=$(docker exec splice-validator-participant-1 bash -c 'echo $CANTON_PARTICIPANT_POSTGRES_DB')
docker exec splice-validator-postgres-splice-1 pg_dump -U cnadmin "${active_participant_db}" > "${backup_dir}"/"${active_participant_db}"-"$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%:z")".dump```

elements.text: The documentation is clear that there is risk involved. We use a simple script to create a backup to a folder. A separate script is doing the retention and rsync to an offsite storage server so that not included below:

#!/bin/bash

# BACKUP DATABASES
backup_dir="/root/__backups"

mkdir -p "${backup_dir}"

docker exec -i splice-validator-postgres-splice-1 pg_dump -U cnadmin validator > "${backup_dir}"/validator-"$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%:z")".dump

sleep 2

active_participant_db=$(docker exec splice-validator-participant-1 bash -c 'echo $CANTON_PARTICIPANT_POSTGRES_DB')
docker exec splice-validator-postgres-splice-1 pg_dump -U cnadmin "${active_participant_db}" > "${backup_dir}"/"${active_participant_db}"-"$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S%:z")".dump
